markup.content: Here is what you can expect:

content.content: This intake application should take 30-45 minutes
This process includes a review by the various stakeholders and City Departments and final approval by the Detroit City Council
The whole process from intake form to purchase agreement is estimated to take 8 - 12 weeks long
If you are submitting this information on behalf of an entity/  or individual, please use their information (i.e not your own)
You can check your status of your application by going to the Check Application Status section and providing the information given to you upon submittion.
You can finish previously started applications or submitted application by going to the Finish/Edit Previous Application section and providing the information given to you upon submittion/save.

items.name: check-status
items.description: Button to check past application status.

markup.content: If you are seeking a City-Owned or DLBA property,  please use this map to identify eligible properties.
View Property Map

If a property is DLBA owned and apart of a specific program: Sidelot program, rehabbed and ready, Auction  or Own it Now, please use those programs, and do not use this application for those purchases / inquires.
For a successful application, have the following prepared before you proceed:

content.content: City of Detroit taxes are paid (or there is a payment plan in place)
Blight tickets are paid (or there is an agreement in place)
City Owned or Detroit Land Bank Authority property/properties are identified
Proposal for the intended use of the property / properties is prepared and ready to submit
Estimate of total development costs and timeline of project

markup.content: Completing this application does not put a “hold” on any properties.

If you are using agricultural chemicals or pesticides, create a plan on what chemicals and pesticides you will use, how often you will use them and how you will use and store them.  This applies even if you are using organic methods and products.  If you have certification to use these items, have that ready

markup.content: Is the application seeking to purchase or commercial lease the property?
A Commercial Lease is an agreement to lease City of Detroit property for an agreed upon period of time

The first step to negotiating a property’s price is to put in an offer. After you submit an offer, DLBA or DBA will work with you on final pricing. Pricing is based on which Detroit Land Bank Authority or Detroit Building Authority program you are eligible for. The Detroit Land Bank Authority and Detroit Building Authority sell property at fair market value.
Enter your offer.

Properties are priced using fair market value.  DBA owned land may be more expensive than land owned by the Detroit Land Bank Authority due to the location or special features. DBA brokers recommended pricing based on comparable sales and other market values.

Fair market value  for a property means that prices may be higher in an area where market demand is increasing land costs nearby.  Prices also may be higher for commercial or specially zoned properties
The range for a typical 3,200 sf residential lot as of 2019 is $800-$1,600, but this can be higher in some neighborhoods based onmarket demand. Commercial properties often cost far more.
Select the primary use for the property

content.content: I acknowledge that failure to disclose a material fact or to misrepresent a fact can result in a rejection of my application.
I certify that all of the information contained in my application to purchase is true and correct.
I understand by signing this, I am authorizing the Owner, its affiliates and agents to conduct a credit check and additional background checks, as applicable.
I acknowledge that the Owner, its affiliates and agents may decline my offer for any reason or no reason.

I acknowledge that the property(ies) that I am seeking is(are) subject to all land use and zoning requirements and restrictions, and I agree that I must comply with all applicable land use, zoning, and property maintenance laws and ordinances.  I understand and agree that it is my sole responsibility to determine whether the zoning permits my intended use.

I acknowledge that the Owner is only offering property "AS IS" with no warranty whatsoever.   I understand that I am assuming the risks for any and all defects in the property. Applicant assumes the responsibility to investigate.
I acknowledge that the Owner is conveying the property via Quit Claim Deed, and does not warrant a title.

I certify that I (or principal or officer if on behalf of a partnership or corporation or affiliated companies) am not in default for the payment of income taxes or property taxes payable to the City of Detroit.
I certify that I (or any principal or officer if on behalf of a partnership or corporation or affiliated companies), have no unpaid blight violations owing to the City of Detroit.
I understand that if the Owner discovers that I have outstanding blight tickets or taxes at any time prior to the closing, the closing may be delayed until all outstanding balances have been paid.
I certify that I (or any principal or officer if on behalf of a partnership or corporation or affiliated companies) have no unpaid water bills owing to the City of Detroit.
I certify that I have read, understand, and agree to be bound by all the terms of this application.   I further certify that all of the statements set forth in this application are complete and true.
I certify that I am authorized to execute this application on behalf of the applicant.

markup.content: If you successfully purchase a property from the City, the property must be cleared of any debris within 30 days of closing. To make sure you are able to do this, please tell us about what the property (or properties) you would like to purchase are like right now and how you will fix any issues or problems so they are ready for your project.
Provide the following:

content.content: Issue description
Action or strategy
Estimated time needed to address issue

markup.content: Please attach and submit photos taken from the sidewalk which show the current condition of the properties you would like to purchase. (Please do not enter the property.)

items.name: current-condition-files
items.description: Photos taken from the sidewalk which show the current condition of the properties you would like to purchase..

markup.content: Physical Improvements Description: Please attach a list of physical improvements you will be making to the property, including any new structures or the demolishing of existing structures. When creating your list, please consider the following items:

content.content: Structures: Will your project include any built structures or uses,such as hoop houses / high tunnels, sheds, storage containers,garages, gazebos, or other structures? If you are planning to build a structure over 120 square feet in size (with the exception of a hoop house), please note that you will need extra permitting  in order to do so when you are ready to start building your project.
Fences and Borders: Will you have a fence or any other way of defining the edge of your project?
Signage: You should include a sign for your project that has the name of your project, your name, and your phone number.
Other Physical Improvements: Tell us about other physical improvements and investments you will be making at the site.

markup.content: These may include, but are not limited, to the following:

content.content: Compost: If you will be storing compost on your site, it should be stored toward the rear of the site and be 20 ft from another property. Tell us about how much compost you expect to store  and where you will locate it on the site.
Trees: New trees and preservation of existing trees. Note that having over 9 trees for sale or harvest on one lot creates an orchard, which is a conditional use.
Planting: Flower beds, raised garden beds, in-ground garden beds
Water: How you will get water access to the site
Art: Sculptures, murals, other art pieces

markup.content: Plot Plan: Please submit a plot plan which shows all relevant elements

items.name: current-condition-files
items.description: Plot plan which shows all relevant elements

markup.content: Are you planing to use agricultural chemicals or pesticides?
Attach the following:

content.content: Plan on what chemicals and pesticides I will use, how often I will use them, and how I will use and store them.
Proof of any certifications I hold related to these items.

markup.content: Development Timeline: Please create and attach a development timeline for your project. Your timeline should include items such as:

content.content: Clean up of the land and clearing it of debris. Generally, this must be done within 30 days after closing with a restricted deed but can be adjusted depending on weather and existing conditions.
Total time it will take to set up and complete your project. This is typically done within 12 to 18 months, but you can indicate whether you need more time.

items.labelText: Property clean up and site preparation

items.labelText: Stipends or contractual services (i.e paid labor or outsourced specialty services)

The first step to negotiating a property’s price is to put in an offer. After you submit an offer, DLBA or DBA will work with you on final pricing. Pricing is based on which Detroit Land Bank Authority or Detroit Building Authority program you are eligible for. The Detroit Land Bank Authority and Detroit Building Authority sell property at fair market value.
Input your offer below.

Properties are priced using fair market value.  DBA owned land may be more expensive than land owned by the Detroit Land Bank Authority due to the location or special features. DBA brokers recommended pricing based on comparable sales and other market values.

Fair market value  for a property means that prices may be higher in an area where market demand is increasing land costs nearby.  Prices also may be higher for commercial or specially zoned properties
The range for a typical 3,200 sf residential lot as of 2019 is $800-$1,600, but this can be higher in some neighborhoods based on market demand. Commercial properties often cost far more

markup.content: A public gathering may include concerts, festivals, parades, picnics or block parties
What dates are you requesting the lease for?
If lease is a long term lease (longer than 30 days) you will be required to be compliant with City zoning.
Is this for a special event?
Add in list of special events that require a permit
Do you have a special event permit?
Having approval for a special event is separate from approval to use city property.
You can apply for a special events permit here:
Visit event permit page.

A Petitioner is required to obtain a Special Events Permit from the Detroit City Council to conduct any event in the public right-of-way or outdoors on private property where the general public is invited.
Events that do not need to follow this process are: Residential Block Parties and Private Invitation Only events held inside a private facility.
Application for a special events permit can happen concurrently with application for a commercial lease.
Is this lease related to a city contract?
Having a city contract does not guarantee access to city-owned land.
Please enter contract information.
Having a city contract does not guarantee access to city-owned land.
